hypotheses: Increasing consumer affluence leads to a decline in manufacturing employment.
Productivity growth in manufacturing sectors contributes to deindustrialization.
Globalization and trade affect manufacturing jobs.
claim.hypotheses_location: Methodologies and Results sections of the original paper.
claim.statement: Explaining Deindustrialization: How Affluence, Productivity Growth, and Globalization Diminish Manufacturing Employment.
claim.statement_location: Title and introduction of the original paper.

data.source: OECD databases, including Annual National Accounts and International Trade databases.
data.wave_or_subset: Data from 18 OECD countries over a 34-year period (1970-2003)
data.access_details: Data accessed from public OECD databases
data.notes: Potential issues with outlier data (Norway 1999-2003, Belgium 1998-1999) were detected and addressed.

method.description: A two-way fixed-effects regression model was used to analyze panel data, incorporating explanatory variables and controlling for factors like productivity growth, trade flows, and affluence.
steps: Collect panel data from OECD countries for the period 1970-2003.
Use fixed-effects regressions to analyze the impact of affluence, productivity, and trade on manufacturing employment.
Control for unbalanced productivity growth through squared and cubic income terms.
Account for outliers and potential biases using robust statistical tests.
method.outcome_variable: Manufacturing employment as a percentage of workforce
method.independent_variables: National affluence, productivity growth, global trade flows
method.tools_software: Stata, used for regression and statistical tests

results.summary: Rising consumer affluence was the most significant factor in deindustrialization, with productivity growth and globalization also contributing.

metadata.original_paper_title: Explaining Deindustrialization: How Affluence, Productivity Growth, and Globalization Diminish Manufacturing Employment
